replies.text:
‚Äã@rippspeck it appears that not a day goes by in the USA without somebody shooting multiple people, hence my question since people seem tired of talking about them.

According to a 2012 Guardian article on gun homicides, the average per 100k people gun homicide rate was 4.9 globally, 3.0 for the US, and 0.4 for Europe (not counting Kosovo, Montenegro, and Russia due to missing data).

In for example 1956 when US schools had gun safety classes, Wikipedia only lists a page for Asia. 1954 had one mass shooting in the US Capitol though. The total US population, including Armed Forces overseas, was about 162,414,000 on July 1, 1954, based on the 1950 Census.
1/162,414,000*100,000 = 0.0006 mass shootings (which includes school shootings) per 100k people.

In 2024 however, with only 340.1 million people, there were 586 mass shootings according to Wikipedia, so 586 / 340.1e6 * 100000 = 0.1723 per 100k people. A 280 times increase.

I‚Äôm tired of debating, but I have to point out, that you seem to be conflating the AR-15 as an assault rifle,

replies.author: @bobsteve4812
replies.text: @josephburke2553I‚Äôm certain it is both of these things!

replies.author: @josephburke2553
@jpe1
replies.text:
@josephburke2553 the term ‚ÄúAR-15‚Äù is a bit vague, in popular usage ‚ÄúAn Ar-15‚Äìstyle rifle‚Äù is a lightweight semi-automatic rifle based on, or similar to, the Colt AR-15 design. The Colt model removed the selective fire feature of its predecessor, the original ArmaLite AR-15, which is a scaled-down derivative of the AR-10 design (by Eugene Stoner). It is closely related to the military M16 rifle. ArmaLite sold the patent and trademarks for both to Colt's Manufacturing Company in 1959 after the military rejected the design in favor of the M14. After most of the patents for the Colt AR-15 expired in 1977, many firearm manufacturers began to produce copies of the rifle under various names. While the patents are expired, Colt has retained the trademark to the AR-15 name and is the sole manufacturer able to label their firearms as such.  My point is that there are copycat rifles to the Colt AR-15 being sold as ‚ÄúAR-15 style‚Äù rifles, so getting all OCD and ‚Äòwell akshully‚Äô about nomenclature is beside the point, which is that the AR-15 *is* an assault rifle, given the definition that matters, the one made by the US Federal Government.  From 1994 to 2004, the Federal Assault Weapons Ban restricted the sale of the Colt AR-15 and some derivatives in the United States, although it did not affect rifles with fewer listed features.  In 2009 by the US National Shooting Sports Foundation coined the term ‚Äúmodern sporting rifle‚Äù in an attempt to deflect attention from the fact that the AR-15 had been considered an assault rifle by the government.
To me the irony of all the debate comes from the fact that my dad, who was Infantry in WWII, was a big fan of the M1 Garand, and that was the rifle I learned to shoot as a kid, and I suspect that the current popularity of AR-15 style rifles is due to good marketing, not inherently superior quality or design.  Plus, the sheeple like to own what they think soldiers like to use.

replies.author: @BambiTrout
replies.text:
‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†@TheSunsetHero256 Not every point has to be extended to the most extreme version of that argument. You seriously took "Slander doesn't harm the dead; it harms the truth" and jumped all the way to "How dare you justify desecrating a corpse!!". 

Charlie Kirk's reputation should be mud. His words alone are enough to condemn him, let alone his actions in helping to establish and justify a government that has devastated the lives of millions of Americans. He was a cruel, petty little man whose life revolved around gleefully spreading hatred towards minority groups and manufacturing consent for their persecution. It is a lie to pretend otherwise - that he was merely a simple defender of free speech who happily debated any and all people in good faith.

I could say that I'm sorry that he's dead, but frankly, that would be a lie. I don't agree with political violence. I think murder is wrong, and every human has intrinsic value. I regret the pain and sorrow his death has caused for those who genuinely loved him as a person. That being said, I'm not going to sit here and pretend that I wish he were still alive. I don't celebrate his death, but I understand those who did - because they were celebrating the death of someone who actively sought to ruin their lives and the lives of those they care about. 

What truly disgusts me is how those who professed to care about him as a person have gleefully celebrated his death as an opportunity to achieve their political aims - using him explicitly as a human sacrifice. It's obscene, and deeply disrespectful - although I would hazard a guess that Kirk would have happily seen his death used as a tool to crush those he wanted to oppress.

'Cause that's the great part: 99% of people don't want corpses desecrated. Folks in this comment chain and Three Arrows have put forward this argument that's universally agreed to be absurd. Again, not my fault that you didn't bother considering the idea to it's conclusion.

This is going to be a fun one to unpack. Short version: You're wrong. Longer version: Countless folks like you have confronted Kirk, over and over and over again about how he's everything you just listed. Every single time not one person could actually back the claim up. Because Kirk isn't anything like how you've characterized him. You only get to this mindset about the guy by intentionally avoiding his actual words and arguments by forming your opinion off the characterization by others. And this is patently obvious to half the country that watched him die. 

In your moral grandstanding, you fail to realize losing one Charlie Kirk created a million Charlie Kirks. So you can try to play games with your made up version of his character, while every single thing you hate about him is multiplied and magnified across the country and world. It's entirely avoidable, but you guys can't help yourselves. Enemies aren't capable of nuance or principled positions. They must be destroyed at all costs. And so you slander his name. So you celebrate his death and call for the deaths of others like Kirk. I don't care if you haven't done this personally. Leftists have so many demons on their side, and they play defense for the demons, I don't care anymore. You guys are demons, and it's not up for discussion.

"Using him as a human sacrifice." That requires that the right have killed Kirk. Which is a claim you can only make if Leftists are so deranged, so possessed by an animalistic urge to kill, that they lack accountability for their actions, sure. I'll agree to that. Then it really is the victim's fault. No, what you're really doing is looking at the people who loved Charlie Kirk in-life, following his lead and not letting his sacrifice go to waste. Because he was sacrificed. He was sacrificed on the demonic alter your people worship. Like a cultist chant, every single day you demons say "He's a fascist!" "He's ruining lives!" "He's taking away our freedom!" "He's killing democracy!" "N@*s need to be attacked!" Violent rhetoric, day after day after day, then someone with the means acts out the logical conclusion of that rhetoric. That was the sacrifice, and like good demons, you cheered. Celebrated. Thanked your god that he's dead. 

And you don't see a problem. Oh well. I'm not here to warn you or to save you. I'm here to say "I told you so". See you in a year.

replies.author: @Max5Lotus
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@Swekyde The tldr is that he went from critical theory and systemic critique to interpersonal, moralizing, liberal identity defense. 

I‚Äôve followed him for years. One example is his video critiquing Robin DiAngelo, which had a strong thesis against neoliberal thought. He correctly avoided blaming men for systemic issues there‚Äîbut now he does exactly that.

He doesn‚Äôt handle feminism well. He sticks to identity politics, which are essentially liberal moral arguments rather than systemic critiques like those in critical theory. Critical theory is dialectical, but he‚Äôs become binary, often essentializing groups like men as the ‚Äúoutgroup.‚Äù

In the Robin DiAngelo video, he critiqued her for blaming all white people interpersonally rather than addressing systems and structures. He said it would be wrong if he did the same about men‚Äîbut now he does. This shift shows a move away from dialectical thinking toward oversimplified binaries.

It became clear to me that he prioritizes his donor base over principles or consistent, well-sourced thought. Even when he references Foucault, he misapplies him‚Äîlike claiming people with autism or ADHD just aren‚Äôt trying hard enough, which is the exact kind of disciplining, normative logic Foucault critiques.

Ironically, he also banned anyone who disagreed with him on the autism point, which is another twist against the spirit of Foucault‚Äôs ideas.

Sure, I disagree with Kirk on the fact that the families referenced had to go through that, but I understand that the people who might defend that position, are concerned with the possibility that the baby might survive (I still oppose this because it is unlikely and the family shouldn't be forced by the state to have it, but understand the point doesn't come from evil, and they're not "ok" with the baby dying) and in their view, that would be better than letting somebody take the life of the fetus because they think it's murder.

Using this guy's exact same logic, in the view of a rightoid, you are responsible as a pro-choice of the deaths of potential human beings, who will be robbed of any experience because their parents decided you were not maybe economically convenient or another reason (I think the abortion case presented in the video is very reasonable, but doesn't change the pro-choice position on other cases).
That's why Charlie held a debate platform, on the principle that you discuss these difficult subjects.
You don't have to think he was a good person, but this moral relativism about "let's compare suffering" in order to discredit the impact of a murder is beyond ridiculous.

replies.author: @AreYouSerious-210g
replies.text:
@DiegoCardona-pe9vr Stochastic terrorism is the repeated use of dehumanizing and inflammatory rhetoric by a public figure that inspires unpredictable, ideologically motivated violence. The term highlights how influential speakers can provoke "lone wolf" attacks while maintaining plausible deniability, since they do not directly order or coordinate the violence.

 A key element of stochastic terrorism is the use of media for propagation, where the person carrying out the violence may not have direct connection to any other users of violent rhetoric.

replies.text:
‚Äã@stlchucko I wonder why leftists make fun of right wing schizo conspiracies while all you do is say your opponents are evil manipulators with hidden intentions. Chill bro and quit imagining things I didn't say...

Let's go one by one:
1) "How is Kirk wishing for bailout not justifying?"
Easily. His argument was "People constantly get released over that the next day, but he was not". He did not justify violence. He did not agree with the punishment.
2) "But he wished for Biden to get the death penalty"
And? Yes, that's because he believed Biden was a criminal. Guess what is civilized way to deal with such issue? Use court and find the truth. Guess what isn't?? Suggesting violence. 
Do you not see the difference between this methods? First leads to a fair process (as much as it can be), the second leads to terrorism.
3) "He justified gun violence because he justified 2nd amendment"
That's terrible logic. Promoting and accepting the cost is nothing close. If you wanna have a baby, you're going to suffer during birth giving. Does it mean you want the suffering?? No, it only means you see it as the most rational choice you can have, considering the cost.

It's like saying we should not have police, because some policemen violate human rights. An illusion that somehow a world is gonna be all rainbow and peace.

4) Your position on David is moot, how can you defend Charlie on his stance.
I'm gonna ignore your paranoid comment on my stance and say next:
I don't agree with Charlie on that. So? In your world view it's either black or white? Either fully defend Charlie or justify his murder?

Now questions to you:
Do you condemn the assassination?
Do you think calling someone a fascist increase or decrease the violence?
Do you believe it would be justified to end Musk or Trump?

replies.author: @AAAitsburningyoureyes
replies.text:
@bbro1810 I did read from the BBC about Charlie Kirk working with people of color, and I know some people took certain quotes out of context (not all of them but for instance the ‚Äúempathy‚Äù quote, which was really a semantic discussion but I think people believed it to be similar to what Elon Musk said about empathy when it wasn‚Äôt). Charlie Kirk used a lot of long-winded rhetorical devices that made it easy for people to take out of context then and now for a variety of purposes, and it doesn‚Äôt help that there‚Äôs a growing dissatisfaction with a style of political debate that is hosted and posted online by one of the sides within that debate (prone to biased representation).

I honestly didn‚Äôt know much about Charlie Kirk before and still don‚Äôt, but I would say certain positions expressed are quite a bit more conservative than the mainstream (although they may not be Charlie‚Äôs actual positions, as it‚Äôs common to play devil‚Äôs advocate in debate). Shortly before the shooting, I know Charlie Kirk was having some misgivings with supporting Israel, and I do think there is a sizable difference between supporting Israel and supporting Jews. There is also a significant difference between supporting ‚Äúblack‚Äù communities financially or organizationally and viewing an individual as less qualified for their job on the basis of race (even if in the context of hiring quotas or other controversial strategies to reduce hiring bias), as both can be done by the same person at the same time. You can be racist while fighting racism, and you can be bigoted against minorities or be fascist without being an antisemite.

Do I think Charlie Kirk was fascist? I don‚Äôt know enough about Charlie‚Äôs political ideology to determine that, but I do think Charlie had some level of bigoted beliefs. That‚Äôs not justification for being shot, but it might explain the behavior of people afterward who had believed Charlie Kirk‚Äôs (apparently pretty popular??) platform was directly contributing to the suffering they faced.

Sometimes we need to take a step back and realize that a lack of support isn‚Äôt the presence of hate. We need to stop thinking so monolithically that a large group of people are equally celebratory about something, equally hold the same set of views, and are equally guilty for the same crimes. We enter debates presupposing a partisan narrative and never get anything done, and those who can walk away with a simple ‚Äúbut I don‚Äôt believe all those things‚Äù are the ones that narrative can‚Äôt refute, who eventually change the narrative to suit their more fringe politics. If we decide our politics purely on the basis of allegiances and reactions to the actions of others, our political ideologies all become inherently reactionary and relative, so those with clearly defined goals such as the ethnonationalists continue to gain ground. Look at how so many have turned the Charlie Kirk issue (and many others) into Democrat vs Republican or right vs left, but ask yourself who actually has something to gain from that narrative. Good vibes don‚Äôt secure our constitutional rights, so why should bad vibes threaten them? Why should we separate out tragedies by the political affiliations of perpetrators and victims, demand that others repeatedly mourn for ‚Äúours‚Äù first while not proceeding to sacrifice that time for ‚Äútheirs‚Äù, and continue to sacrifice time for our emotional ingroups while we witness the death toll rise for us all? We don‚Äôt have space for the performative outrage of people not feeling the right way out loud when it is the goals and actions of those who have felt privately in some very extreme ways that are deciding the political environment of our nation.

@BlueHares Great job on hitting all the talking points, I noticed you provided nothing to prove he was supportive of any of these ideas other than what you form in your head.

I never said you claimed it only comes from the right, it's the assertion from this comment section that it is the common belief that it does. I was only pointing out these ideals are not right/left, they are the actions undertaken.

Fascism is alive today on the left, The ideal of life as art, the cult of beauty, the fetishism of courage, the dissolution of alienation in ecstatic feeling of community, the family of man under the parenthood of leaders. 

These are the ideal held by the public that allow for authoritarianism to rear up and bite us all.

Fundamentally what is fascism? I'd argue it's simply forced revolutionary change and total control. 

I became politically homeless a decade ago after 30 years of being left; not because my world view changed, but because of the euphemistic treadmill I was forced to walk on and the dogmatic ideals that were closed to criticism. These are illiberal ideologies that have infected the left for the past 20 years or so.

Finally, your appeal to credentialism is a fallacy and shows no depth of thought.

text: I have a friend who was encouraged by her family and a extreme religious group (after she left our church) to not get a so-called late-term abortion after finding out her baby would not survive her needed cancer treatment. She went through the full pregnancy and labor. The baby was stillborn and clearly had stopped growing at least a month prior. It broke her brain. My friend has never been the same and talks about this child that never lived as another one of her kids. It's been 15 years and she still breaks down about it. It impacts her other children. It's torture for people who can give birth to be forced or coerced into going through full pregnancies and giving birth to dying or dead babies. I believe people that do this just want to punish mothers they see as "bad". Like their baby would have survived if they were a better person or something. replies.author: @zericle1
replies.text:
‚Äã@TheBohemianCat I think Floyd was a guy that was murdered by a cop that was out of line. Whether it was racially motivated, I really don't know. Some people argue it clearly is, I feel it's more of a subjective feeling for a lot of people. I remember the riots that followed being pretty destructive. Lots of shop owners lost their businesses. However, that whataboutism doesn't justify Kirk's hatred that ultimately leads to many crazy people on the right grabbing their guns and deciding to shoot up a bunch of random people in churches and parking lots because the woke minority group mind virus is going to destroy America or whatever stupid thing is on these lunatic's minds. 

There was violence on both sides over the past 10 years, but the right's violence has been much more destructive. More people die in shootings caused by people with right-leaning views than left-leaning ones. Ultimately I think people need to calm the hell down.

And before anyone says "don't both sides things" No, I will both sides this. I will, and you want to know why? I don't want to be part of a hivemind. If you don't criticize your own side then you're being one-sided. If you're being one-sided you aren't getting the full picture. You aren't getting the actual truth, just half of it. And the full truth is uncomfortable, so get used to it.

I'm personally done with taking sides. Being team left or team right. But I still champion views that I consider good causes. I think the left has more of those good causes, but I'm not going to jump at the bit to support a politician just because they're on a team. I support people that I think have good ideas, and that's it. There's no left idea, no right idea, there are just ideas that work and those that don't. There are many corrupt, spineless, and stupid people milling about in both parties. People on both sides have trouble coming to terms that their politicians, their very beloved politicians are corrupt just as much the bad politicians that they're taught to hate. If I don't know enough about a subject, then I don't take sides. You don't need to take a side for everything. Have you ever actually thought about how every single view under the sun can be classified as a right or left leaning view? Why should that even be the case? Every single thing is politicized. Why is that? There's quite literally nothing that you can believe in anymore without somebody calling you a fascistic pig or a woke libtard. And if you believe in two things from both sides then nobody likes you. If you're moderate and just want people to get along then nobody likes you. It's really really dumb if you actually think about it. Our society can't keep going on like this. Eventually some ideas will have to become considered neither left nor right if we want society to function. People will continue to be fighting with each other as long as there's two teams for everything. 

There. That's my take. If you hate me for it, then I ask you to be less hateful. Hate is what's destroying our country at this very moment. Both sides think their hatred for the other is justified. Maybe it is, but it's still hate at the end of the day. I've had my share of that. At the end of the day, after all of this, we're still going to need to find a way to get along. Our president is certainly not helping keep people united despite our differences. We're the United States. What we need is a president that can unite us. The people will follow by example, and we can put this whole mess of a time behind us. All I want is at least some person with dignity in our highest office. Somebody who can turn down the temperature, and someone who cares about facts over their party's feelings on the facts. Honestly I care more about that than any culture war things. Why should I needlessly stress out over trans people and their pronouns or evangelical pro-life people everyday? Why should I sacrifice my mental health, my time, and my faith to placate and suck-up to groups of people that I barely ever interact with? Being normal is comforting in a time when everyone wants to be the farthest thing from normal.

My point with writing all of this is that I wish people would just quit being so stuck in their ways and actually try to understand each other a little better. Yeah okay, maybe their beliefs make you uncomfortable or disgusted, but these people are your neighbors. These are people you'll be sharing a country with for the next decades to come, maybe you should make an effort to get along somehow.

replies.text: @CTimmerman I think if the framers meant "army" they would have said "army." That was a word in the vernacular at the time, but they chose "militia." They wanted a contingent of civilians who could be mustered to supplement defense, and in order to do that, arms should not be kept from them. But that's where the crux is - does that mean everybody in the land gets a gun, or do you have guns secured in an armory that you draw from? I feel like it should be more the latter.

And other than that, well, the perception of words and their meanings of course that's not "bullshit". It would be foolish to assume that a word will have the same exact meaning for everyone, specially on stuff like empathy, or justice, or love. I'm sure that someone you know has said what love means to them, for example, and you might not agree with it. It might be the same, no?

replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@aberrant-thoughtspace-entityWell, it looks like we agree on a point: claims, especially controversial ones, need to be backed up.
My original focus wasn't to defend Kirk, but to apply that scrutiny. Whether you call it trolling or asking questions, my point is that citing specific evidence is how we move beyond assumption and accusation.
You mention he "literally cycles through like 18 right wing dog whistles" and talks about vaccines not working and surviving COVID with vitamins. Those are very specific claims. If you could point me to a direct clip or quote of him saying something like, 'only one gender can give birth' or the stuff about vitamins, that would be appreciated, as is your burden to give proof when you say that, you cant just say "hey, it's there, look it up" when you are the one sustaining that those things back up your argument.
Giving evidence is the only way to hold anyone accountable and have a discussion that isn't just about 'whose side sucks ass more'.

People can be horrible human beings, but they are still human beings.  Normalizing dehumanization is the first step towards great atrocities being justified.  It's been done on the left and right throughout modern history.  We shouldn't think it's ok just when 'our side' does it.

author: @Zarathinius
text: "He was just a guy with a podcast" and "words aren't violence" reminds me of my hypothesis: possibly the biggest difference in reactionary/conservative worldviews from everyone else is either an inability, or a deliberate refusal, to acknowledge secondary effects. Everything in their universe (as they describe it, anyway; who knows what goes on in their minds) is One Cause, One Effect, Done. Second-order impacts are just... not a thing they are willing to acknowledge. The fact that political speech doesn't end with simply being heard, but has a very obvious secondary effect of political action, is simply not acknowledged. It's all Just Talk, and if an action happens, that can't possibly be related.

replies.author: @kristelbrok998

I still remember when a brain dead black mother on life support in Georgia was forced to give birth to her baby. She died a few days later and it has never left my mind ever since. Her name was Adriana Smith and she deserves to be remembered, not Charlie Kirk.

replies.text:
‚Äã@GujoPopeePlease look up the case before talking about it, as you clearly don't understand the situation. Smith died on February 19th. She was only 8 weeks pregnant by then.
They kepy her dead body on life support for several MONTHS to let it grow the baby. It was then removed via cesarean in June.

The baby wasn't almost due. The baby was barely a fetus the size of a raspberry by the time Smith died.

Also, her family was absolutely horrified. They absolutely did not want this

The baby was extremely premature, making him at risk for health issues on short and long term.

And pro-lifers, who wanted this child to be born from a dead mother, are not the ones voting for childcare, support for poor kids and their parents, for healthcare, for free school meals, etc. No, they only care about a fetus until it's born. What happens to this baby, and many others, isn't their concern and they do not care.

author: @-tera-3345
text: You know, it occurs to me that so many of the people endlessly going on about how disgusting it is that some people are happy Kirk is gone are the same people who would be partying in the street if instead it had been, say, Joe Biden.

replies.author: @00PlPu00
replies.text: I'd be happy for both tbh

replies.author: @mostlysure1077
replies.text: No. And it's gross that you think that. Joe Biden's age was endearing, even if you disagreed with him. Not to mention that Joe isn't exactly a super leftist. He's always been a big compromise and please nobody specific kind of guy. He has a nuanced political history to say the least.

replies.author: @-tera-3345
replies.text:
@mostlysure1077 I have met enough otherwise fairly normal people who would then go on to talk about Biden as if he were the literally the devil incarnate and would completely destroy America if he got elected / re-elected. And I mean like, personally met and spoken with, not just seen some random posts online that were probably by trolls or bots. Some of whom I have directly seen go on to currently talking about how disgusting "the left" is treating Kirk's murder. While somehow being completely blind to the disgusting ways commentators on the right have been treating it.

Personally, I think outright denying that phenomenon as even existing and refusing to acknowledge what caused it is what's gross. Because people like Kirk and those currently lionizing him in the media are the ones directly responsible for it.

replies.author: @mostlysure1077
replies.text:
‚Äã@-tera-3345‚ÄãFirstly, that's unfortunate you annecdotal experience with anomolous right wingers. It hasn't been my experience at all with the conservatives I know.

Secondly, people were saying the same thing about Trump as Biden, too, tbh, except actually saying they hoped for his assassination. It's important to note that Charlie Kirk wasn't running the country so we can understand who exactly is being celebrated for dying here. Wanting the assassination of your country's leader, of course, isn't acceptable, but it is expected and seen throughout the world like in Australia or people's reactions to the Queen dying. Charlie's job was to be the messenger, not the leader. 

Thirdly, the media isn't directly responsible for people's behavior. They're indirectly responsible. It's still mostly the people's responsibilities to think for themselves.

Fourthly, if there was a political assassination of Biden unless they're hardcore Trump cultists, they wouldn't condone it publically on Tic-Tok. Right wingers have kind of been on the side that does more private political assessinations for the longest time. They at least know it's a bad thing to do and to keep it private. George Floyd, for example, they knew not to celebrate publically were they to be evil enough to celebrate it.

Fifthly, the left constantly uses rhetoric against the right that the right is violent. You don't throw stones in a glass house.

Finally, the people lionizing charlie kirk are setting a good moral precident for behavior in the right. Political violence is now off the table for the right. This is a good thing. I don't get how everyone here seems to be twisting it as bad.

replies.author: @-tera-3345
replies.text:
@mostlysure1077 Your not personally knowing anyone is ALSO anecdotal. Stop being disingenuous.

People also being afraid of Trump getting elected or being sad that he didn't die really doesn't have any bearing on whether or not people trying to tone police the current situation would have celebrated a similar one for one of their enemies. I'm not even sure what you're trying to argue with that. But also, don't try to "both sides" it when only one of those sides actively tried to overthrow election results.

The current media landscape being largely responsible for the increasing political divide is pretty commonly accepted. You can't expect people to be personally responsible when they're only being fed heavily biased and often entirely incorrect information. Unless you're expecting them to be more responsible at seeking out more accurate information, in which case I hate to break it to you, but going by most third-party fact checking organizations, it's people listening to right wing media that are far less responsible.

You referring to Floyd as a "political assassination" is bizarre and seems to demonstrate a somewhat warped view of politics. And while there may not have been people celebrating it, there were no end to people saying it was just and deserved. I don't know what timeline you come from. But for a more recent example, you only need to look to the attack on Nancy Pelosi's husband, where plenty of people were memeing on and joking about it. But those are just random people online? So are most the people saying they're happy about Kirk. Don't be unfair.

What leftist with a major platform on a national level that reaches millions of people uses explicitly violent rhetoric? Because many of the right-wing commentators using it ARE at that level. Take care of your own glass house first. But again, "the left does it too!" is kind of completely irrelevant to my point.

I don't know how you can look at the public comments made by right wing figures and claim that violence has been taken off the table for them. They've all almost exclusively used it as an opportunity to rally for more political power for themselves while attacking the left and minorities. I haven't seen any of them talk about who Kirk was as a person or celebrate his life. Calling that morally good really just makes me question your morality.

You called me gross for making a comment based on my personal experience and are now trying to deny that experience while also bringing in a whole bunch of points that I never made. Without ever retracting the original insult. You're not interested in having a good faith discussion, so I will not continue it any further.

replies.author: @nathanielbellmore
replies.text: Most people on all sides fight fire with fire and wonder why the world is burning.

replies.author: @mostlysure1077
replies.text:
‚Äã@-tera-3345By the same token, your annecdotal evidence is also invalid. Where does that leave us? 

People being sad that Trump didn't get successfully assassinated has bearing because that means it's an issue from both sides and is normal. The Joe Biden example, even if true, is not a good comparative to Kirk since Biden was president it's normal for presidents. It's also extremely disengenuous of you to bring up the election overthrow, when only one side actually tried, and failed, to assassinate Trump. 

I'm not sure why you're bringing up the political divide. It has little to do with people actually celebrating assassination. Same thing goes for people on the right, working class as they are, not having the time of day to be politically informed. It's still their decision to actually act on their limited politics and celebrate murder or not. 

Floyed was a political assaasination. His skin color 100% had to do with it. You calling it "bizarre" doesn't take that away. People weren't saying it was just and deserved for the reason you suggest. You're manipulating the fact that they thought that way in the first place because they thought, incorrectly or not, that police holding people with a knee is due process and he shouldn't have been unlawfully high. 

People were memeing on the attack of Nancy Pelosi's husband because the guy was a Qanon conspiricy theorist wacko, it was absurd what the attacker was trying, and her husband wasn't actually killed. It's again, not a fair comparison, just like your Joe Biden one. There are few examples of political assassinations of publically popular people from the right, unless we go all the way back to MLK. 

People keep saying as you are, also, that Kirk had "violent" rhetoric. But every time I look up the quote and find the context, it's taken out of it. It's not at all what he was saying. He was pro-life. That's the most violent thing he believed. Again, leftists shouldn't be throwing around "violence" in a glass house. If you're fine that you're in the same party as people who openly admit they like assassination without you disowning them as ShoeOnHead did, then you can't go and call out people on the right. If you, right now, disown the people who celebrate his murder from your political stance, then we're all holding eachother to a higher precident, and that's a good thing. 

Also, I struggle finding actual specific examples of right wingers using charlie's death to gain substantial political power specifically in order to call for violence. Charlie himself would roll in his grave. 

Further, I wasn't calling you gross. I was calling what you were saying gross, just like how you went and called what I was saying gross. I'm not going to be a coward and accuse you of not arguing in good faith, because I'm above that. I realize that people think things I don't, for reasons I don't always peg exactly. Occam's razor, however, says to assume ignorance rather than malice, because it assumes less

author: @justdirt
text:
I think the disconnect is that some people simply do not have the empathy to understand why someone would cheer when a terrible person dies. They might understand when a rape victim cheers when their rapist dies, but the concept of non-physical harm being done is beyond them. "Kirk was just saying words, he had no impact on anything, he never hurt anyone physically," is genuinely how these people think. Politics isn't a matter of life or death, suffering, torture, fear, etc to these people. To them, politics is making their money go up and anyone harmed to do so is whatever. 

So many of these conservatives who are mad at people celebrating Kirk's death want to be able to tell people to mourn their abusers deaths. Because to them, Charlie never did anything wrong. They are too simple minded or rather, too immature to comprehend that words have power. Its for a similar reason they think Trump did nothing wrong on Jan 6th.

author: @Neneset
text: The same people who are demanding that we whitewash Kirk's legacy are often the same people who mocked Nancy Pelosi's husband after he was bludgeoned with a hammer by a MAGA supporter who broke into their San Francisco home with the intention of killing Nancy Pelosi, who was in Washington, DC at the time.  People who immediately and without evidence posted claims that the man who assassinated Minnesota state representative Melissa Hortman, her husband and attempted to assassinate Minnesota State Senator John Hoffman and his wife was a radical leftist, communist.  Something they immediately did with Kirk's assassin as well.  Their demands of civility and charitable reconsiderations of one's legacy only extend to those on the right. When political violence is dealt to those on the left, or center in the case of the Pelosis, then not only are there no calls for civility, but instead there is unfettered mocking and insulting of those who were attacked and/or killed.  This makes it very hard to take their demands seriously.  The social contract goes both ways or it doesn't go any ways.

replies.author: @bulletsandbracelets4140
replies.text: The only valid "both sides" argument is that both sides have a ton of politicians in the pockets of lobbyists.  But they curiously never talk about that. And that doesn't even begin to get into the countless other ways they are different, like you said.  There's ways to equate them that point out actual changes necessary in our politics, but instead of getting to have those conversations, we have to deal with the rising tide of fascism instead.  It's exhausting trying to talk to people who see this whole thing as some simple good vs evil plot where either Dems are saviors or Dems are the ultimate evil alongside Republicans.  When really it's just... complicated, and we have to do what we can when we can.
